name: TCP/IP
description: The Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and Internet Protocol (IP) form the fundamental protocol suite for network communication. TCP provides reliable, connection-oriented data transport at Layer 4, while IP handles logical addressing and routing at Layer 3.
key_topics: TCP vs UDP characteristics and use cases
Port numbers and well-known service ports
TCP window sizing and flow control
IPv4 packet structure and header fields
Maximum Segment Size (MSS) and Path MTU Discovery
common_misconceptions: Many training materials oversimplify TCP window sizing â€” the Cisco IOS configuration guide shows how window scaling actually works and how the tcp window-size command affects performance
Third-party resources often confuse the MSS (Maximum Segment Size) with MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit). Cisco documentation clarifies that MSS = MTU - IP header - TCP header
Training books sometimes state TCP always uses a three-way handshake, but Cisco's config guides document TCP Fast Open and other optimizations that modify this behavior
Common misconception: UDP is 'unreliable' and should be avoided. Cisco documentation shows UDP is preferred for real-time applications like VoIP where speed matters more than guaranteed delivery
